metadata.subject: Physical Sciences
metadata.contentDescriptor: Apply the law of conservation of energy to analyse energy transformations and transfers in physical systems

A.levelDescription: Simplified concepts with visual support for students working 2-3 years below year level
whatYouWillLearn: What energy is and why it's important
The different types of energy
How energy changes from one form to another
Why energy cannot be created or destroyed
How Australia uses and produces energy

sections.title: What is Energy?
sections.content: Energy is the ability to make things happen - to move things, heat things, light things up, or make sounds. You can't see energy itself, but you can see what it does. When you throw a ball, you give it energy. When you turn on a heater, electrical energy becomes heat. Energy makes everything work - from your body to cars to the entire universe. Scientists measure energy in units called joules (J). The energy in a fast-moving cricket ball is about 150 joules. A typical person uses about 8 million joules of food energy each day!
sections.visualDescription: Illustrations showing various examples of energy in action: moving car, glowing light, person running, heating food

sections.title: Types of Energy
sections.content: There are many types of energy. Kinetic energy is the energy of moving things - the faster something moves and the heavier it is, the more kinetic energy it has. Potential energy is stored energy that can be released later. A stretched rubber band has potential energy; when you let go, it moves. Gravitational potential energy depends on height - a book on a high shelf has more than one on the floor. Other types include thermal energy (heat), light energy, sound energy, electrical energy, and chemical energy (stored in food and fuels). Nuclear energy is stored inside atoms.
sections.visualDescription: Diagram showing different energy types with everyday examples of each

sections.title: Energy Transformations
sections.content: Energy constantly changes from one form to another. When you drop a ball, gravitational potential energy becomes kinetic energy as it falls. When the ball hits the ground, some kinetic energy becomes sound and heat. A light bulb transforms electrical energy into light and heat. Your body transforms chemical energy from food into kinetic energy for movement and thermal energy to keep you warm. These changes are called energy transformations. Every device you use transforms energy from one type to another.
sections.visualDescription: Flow diagram showing energy transformations in a flashlight: chemical (battery) → electrical → light + heat

sections.title: The Law of Conservation of Energy
sections.content: One of the most important laws in science says that energy cannot be created or destroyed - it can only change from one form to another. This is called the law of conservation of energy. If you add up all the energy before something happens and after it happens, the total stays the same. When a ball bounces and eventually stops, the kinetic energy hasn't disappeared - it's been transformed into heat and sound that spread out into the surroundings. Energy is never lost, but it can spread out and become less useful.
sections.visualDescription: Before/after diagram showing a bouncing ball with energy transformations labeled at each stage

sections.title: Work and Energy
sections.content: In science, 'work' has a special meaning. Work is done when a force moves something. If you push a shopping trolley and it moves, you're doing work. If you push a wall and it doesn't move, you're not doing work in the scientific sense, even though you're tired! Work transfers energy from one thing to another. When you lift a book, you do work on it, and the book gains gravitational potential energy. The amount of work equals the energy transferred. Work is measured in joules, the same unit as energy.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison showing 'work being done' (moving a box) versus 'no work done' (pushing an unmovable wall)

sections.title: Power: How Fast Energy Changes
sections.content: Power measures how quickly energy is transferred or transformed. If two people carry the same box up stairs, but one does it faster, the faster person uses more power (though both do the same amount of work). Power is measured in watts (W). A 60-watt light bulb uses 60 joules of electrical energy every second. A kilowatt (kW) is 1000 watts. The electricity you use at home is measured in kilowatt-hours (kWh) - that's 1000 watts used for one hour. Understanding power helps us compare how quickly different devices use energy.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison of power ratings for common devices: phone charger (5W), light bulb (60W), TV (100W), air conditioner (3000W)

sections.title: Energy Efficiency
sections.content: When energy transforms, some usually becomes heat that spreads out and is hard to use again. Efficiency tells us how much useful energy we get compared to the total energy we put in. A traditional light bulb is only about 5% efficient - most energy becomes heat, not light! LED lights are about 80% efficient. Cars are only about 25% efficient - most fuel energy becomes heat. Improving efficiency means we get more useful work from the same amount of energy, which saves money and helps the environment.
sections.visualDescription: Energy efficiency comparison showing LED vs incandescent bulbs with energy flow diagrams

sections.title: Energy in Australia
sections.content: Australia uses lots of energy - for transport, electricity, heating, and industry. Historically, most of our electricity came from burning coal, which releases energy stored millions of years ago in ancient plants. Now, Australia is rapidly building renewable energy - solar panels transform light energy into electricity, and wind turbines transform the kinetic energy of wind. In sunny Queensland and South Australia, rooftop solar provides a large fraction of electricity on bright days. The challenge is storing energy for when the sun isn't shining and the wind isn't blowing.
sections.visualDescription: Map of Australia showing energy sources and major renewable energy installations

caseStudy.title: Snowy 2.0: Giant Battery for Australia
caseStudy.content: Australia is building one of the world's largest 'batteries' - but it doesn't use chemicals like your phone battery. Snowy 2.0 is a pumped hydro project that stores energy using water and gravity. When there's extra electricity (like on a sunny afternoon when solar panels produce lots of power), the system uses that electricity to pump water uphill into a high reservoir. The electrical energy is transformed into gravitational potential energy of the water. Later, when electricity is needed (like in the evening when people turn on lights and cook dinner), the water is released to flow downhill through turbines, transforming its gravitational potential energy back into electrical energy. The system is about 75% efficient - some energy is lost to friction and heat. When complete, Snowy 2.0 will be able to power millions of homes for days during high demand. It works together with solar and wind farms to provide reliable clean energy. The project shows how understanding energy transformations helps solve real-world problems like storing renewable energy.
questions: What types of energy transformation occur when Snowy 2.0 is storing energy?
Why is energy 'lost' when water is pumped uphill and released back down?
How does pumped hydro help make solar and wind energy more reliable?

remember.question: What does the law of conservation of energy state?
remember.sampleAnswer: The law of conservation of energy states that energy cannot be created or destroyed; it can only be transformed from one form to another.

understand.question: Explain why a ball eventually stops bouncing, even though energy is conserved.
understand.sampleAnswer: Each time the ball bounces, some of its kinetic energy is transformed into heat and sound. These forms of energy spread out into the surroundings and can't easily be captured again. The ball has less kinetic energy after each bounce, so it bounces lower and lower until it stops. The total energy is still conserved - it's just been transformed into less useful forms spread throughout the environment.

apply.question: Describe the energy transformations that occur when you switch on a desk lamp and use it to read.
apply.sampleAnswer: Electrical energy from the power grid flows into the lamp. The lamp transforms electrical energy into light energy (which allows you to see) and thermal energy (the lamp feels warm). The light energy travels to your book and is reflected into your eyes, where it is transformed into electrical signals that travel to your brain.

analyse.question: Why are LED lights better for the environment than traditional incandescent bulbs, even though both produce light?
analyse.sampleAnswer: LED lights are much more efficient - about 80% of the electrical energy becomes light, compared to only about 5% for incandescent bulbs. The rest becomes heat. Because LEDs need less electrical energy to produce the same amount of light, power plants need to burn less coal or gas, which means fewer greenhouse gas emissions. Less wasted energy also means lower electricity bills. The higher efficiency makes a big difference when you consider millions of lights running for hours every day.

unistructural.question: What unit is used to measure power?

multistructural.question: List three types of potential energy and give an example of each.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: 1) Gravitational potential energy - a rock at the top of a cliff has gravitational potential energy due to its height. 2) Elastic potential energy - a stretched rubber band or compressed spring stores energy that can be released when released. 3) Chemical potential energy - food and batteries store chemical energy that can be released through chemical reactions.

relational.question: Explain the relationship between work, energy, and power.
relational.sampleAnswer: Work is the transfer of energy from one object or system to another. When a force moves an object, work is done and energy is transferred. Both work and energy are measured in joules. Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred - it tells us how quickly energy changes. Power equals work divided by time, or energy divided by time. So if two people do the same amount of work, but one does it faster, the faster person uses more power. These concepts are connected because work is the mechanism of energy transfer, and power describes how quickly that transfer occurs.

studentReflection: Think about your morning routine - how many energy transformations can you identify?
Why do you think efficiency is so important when we talk about energy?
What would happen if energy could be created or destroyed?

B.levelDescription: Developing complexity and academic vocabulary for students approaching year level expectations
whatYouWillLearn: How to calculate kinetic and potential energy
The relationship between work, force, and displacement
How to apply conservation of energy to physical systems
How to calculate efficiency and power
Energy sources and Australia's energy transition

sections.title: Kinetic Energy: Energy of Motion
sections.content: Kinetic energy (KE) is the energy an object has due to its motion. The faster an object moves and the more massive it is, the more kinetic energy it has. The formula is KE = ½mv², where m is mass in kilograms and v is velocity in metres per second. Notice that velocity is squared - this means doubling the speed quadruples the kinetic energy. A 1000 kg car travelling at 20 m/s has kinetic energy of ½ × 1000 × 20² = 200,000 J. At 40 m/s, the same car has 800,000 J - four times as much. This explains why high-speed crashes are so much more dangerous.
sections.visualDescription: Graph showing kinetic energy versus velocity, demonstrating the squared relationship

sections.title: Gravitational Potential Energy
sections.content: Gravitational potential energy (GPE) is the energy an object has due to its position in a gravitational field. The higher an object is, the more gravitational potential energy it has. The formula is GPE = mgh, where m is mass in kilograms, g is gravitational acceleration (9.8 m/s² on Earth), and h is height in metres. A 2 kg book on a shelf 1.5 m high has GPE = 2 × 9.8 × 1.5 = 29.4 J. If it falls, this potential energy transforms into kinetic energy. At ground level (h = 0), all the energy is kinetic.
sections.visualDescription: Diagram showing an object at different heights with GPE calculated at each level

sections.title: Conservation of Mechanical Energy
sections.content: In a system without friction or air resistance, the total mechanical energy (kinetic + potential) remains constant. As a ball falls, GPE decreases while KE increases, but their sum stays the same. We can write: KE₁ + GPE₁ = KE₂ + GPE₂. This allows us to calculate velocities at different heights. For a ball dropped from 10 m: at the top, KE = 0 and GPE = mgh = 10mg. At the bottom, GPE = 0, so KE = 10mg. Since KE = ½mv², we get ½mv² = 10mg, solving to v = √(20g) ≈ 14 m/s. Energy conservation provides a powerful problem-solving method.
sections.visualDescription: Energy bar charts showing KE and GPE at different points along a falling ball's path

sections.title: Work: The Energy Transfer Mechanism
sections.content: Work is done when a force causes an object to move in the direction of the force. The formula is W = Fd, where W is work in joules, F is force in newtons, and d is displacement in metres. If the force and motion aren't in the same direction, we use the component of force in the direction of motion: W = Fd cos θ. Work is positive when force and motion are in the same direction, negative when opposite (like braking), and zero when perpendicular (like the normal force on a sliding object). Work equals the energy transferred to or from an object.
sections.visualDescription: Diagrams showing work done at different angles between force and displacement

sections.title: Power: Rate of Energy Transfer
sections.content: Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred. The formula is P = W/t or P = E/t, where P is power in watts, W is work or E is energy in joules, and t is time in seconds. Power can also be expressed as P = Fv (force times velocity) for moving objects. A person who runs up stairs faster than another does the same work but uses more power. Household electricity is measured in kilowatt-hours (kWh): 1 kWh = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3,600,000 J. An appliance using 2 kW for 3 hours uses 6 kWh of energy.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison showing two people climbing stairs at different speeds with power calculations

sections.title: Energy Efficiency
sections.content: Efficiency measures how much useful energy output we get compared to total energy input. The formula is: Efficiency = (useful energy output / total energy input) × 100%. A car engine with 100 MJ of fuel energy that produces 25 MJ of kinetic energy has efficiency = (25/100) × 100% = 25%. The remaining 75% becomes heat. No machine is 100% efficient - the second law of thermodynamics guarantees some energy always becomes unusable heat. Improving efficiency reduces energy waste, costs, and environmental impact. Australia's energy efficiency policies set minimum standards for appliances.
sections.visualDescription: Sankey diagrams showing energy flow through various devices with efficiency calculations

sections.title: Energy Sources in Australia
sections.content: Australia's energy comes from various sources. Fossil fuels (coal, gas, oil) contain chemical energy from ancient organisms - burning releases this energy as heat. Nuclear energy comes from mass-energy conversion in atomic nuclei. Renewable sources include: solar (light to electrical via photovoltaics), wind (kinetic to electrical), hydro (gravitational potential to electrical), and geothermal (Earth's internal thermal energy). Australia has abundant solar and wind resources. The challenge is that solar and wind are variable - they don't match demand patterns. Energy storage (batteries, pumped hydro) and grid connections help balance supply and demand.
sections.visualDescription: Australia's energy mix pie chart with trends showing increasing renewable share

sections.title: Energy and Climate Change
sections.content: Burning fossil fuels releases stored carbon as CO₂, a greenhouse gas that traps heat and drives climate change. Energy use is responsible for about 75% of Australia's greenhouse gas emissions. Reducing emissions requires transforming how we generate and use energy: replacing fossil fuel power stations with renewables, electrifying transport, improving efficiency in buildings and industry. The physics of energy transformation underlies both the problem (combustion releasing CO₂) and solutions (renewable generation, efficient technologies). Understanding energy is essential for understanding and addressing climate change.
sections.visualDescription: Diagram connecting energy sources, combustion, CO₂ emissions, and the greenhouse effect

caseStudy.title: Australia's Big Batteries
caseStudy.content: In 2017, South Australia experienced a statewide blackout caused partly by storms damaging infrastructure and challenges managing variable renewable energy. Tesla's Elon Musk offered to build the world's largest lithium-ion battery in 100 days or provide it free. The Hornsdale Power Reserve was completed in 60 days. The battery can store 194 MWh of electrical energy - enough to power about 30,000 homes for an hour. But its main value isn't long-term storage; it's providing rapid response to stabilize the grid. When demand suddenly exceeds supply, the battery can inject power in milliseconds - far faster than any power station can respond. It also participates in 'frequency control' - maintaining the precise 50 Hz frequency that the electricity grid requires. The battery has saved South Australian consumers millions of dollars by reducing the need for expensive backup generators. Since Hornsdale, larger batteries have been built across Australia, including the 450 MWh Victorian Big Battery near Geelong. These projects demonstrate how understanding energy storage and transformation helps solve practical engineering challenges.
questions: What energy transformation occurs when the battery is charging? When discharging?
Why is the battery's speed of response more important than its total storage capacity?
How does the battery help integrate more renewable energy into the grid?

remember.question: State the formula for kinetic energy and define each variable.
remember.sampleAnswer: The formula for kinetic energy is KE = ½mv², where KE is kinetic energy in joules, m is mass in kilograms, and v is velocity in metres per second.

understand.question: Explain why doubling a car's speed more than doubles its stopping distance.
understand.sampleAnswer: Kinetic energy depends on velocity squared (KE = ½mv²), so doubling the speed quadruples the kinetic energy. To stop, the brakes must do work to remove all this kinetic energy. Work equals force times distance (W = Fd). If braking force remains constant, quadrupling the energy means quadrupling the distance needed to stop. Additionally, reaction distance also increases with speed, making total stopping distance more than four times longer.

apply.question: A 0.5 kg ball is dropped from a height of 8 m. Calculate its velocity just before hitting the ground.
apply.sampleAnswer: Using conservation of energy: GPE at top = KE at bottom. mgh = ½mv². The mass cancels: gh = ½v². Rearranging: v = √(2gh) = √(2 × 9.8 × 8) = √156.8 = 12.5 m/s. The ball hits the ground at approximately 12.5 m/s.

analyse.question: A motor uses 5000 J of electrical energy to lift a 40 kg load 10 m in 20 seconds. Calculate the motor's efficiency and power.
analyse.sampleAnswer: Useful energy output = GPE gained = mgh = 40 × 9.8 × 10 = 3920 J. Efficiency = (useful output / input) × 100% = (3920 / 5000) × 100% = 78.4%. Power input = energy / time = 5000 / 20 = 250 W. Power output = 3920 / 20 = 196 W. The motor is 78.4% efficient, with 250 W input power and 196 W useful output power.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the claim that electric vehicles are more efficient than petrol cars, even when the electricity comes from coal-fired power stations.
evaluate.sampleAnswer: This claim is generally true but requires careful analysis. A petrol engine is about 25% efficient; an electric motor is about 85-90% efficient. However, we must consider the full energy chain. Coal power stations are about 35% efficient, with about 5% transmission losses. So electricity from coal reaches the EV with about 33% efficiency. The EV motor then converts this at 85% efficiency, giving overall efficiency from coal to wheels of about 28%. This slightly exceeds petrol cars' 25%. Additionally, EVs recapture energy through regenerative braking, improving efficiency further. The advantage grows dramatically when electricity comes from renewables. So the claim is valid, though the margin is smaller for coal-derived electricity than often assumed.

unistructural.question: What is the unit of measurement for energy?

multistructural.question: List four forms of energy and give one example of each.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: 1) Kinetic energy - a moving car has kinetic energy due to its motion. 2) Gravitational potential energy - water at the top of a dam has potential energy due to its height. 3) Chemical energy - food stores energy that is released through chemical reactions in digestion. 4) Thermal energy - a cup of hot coffee has thermal energy due to the motion of its particles.

relational.question: Explain the relationship between gravitational potential energy and kinetic energy for a ball thrown upward.
relational.sampleAnswer: When a ball is thrown upward, it starts with kinetic energy from the throw. As it rises, it slows down - kinetic energy decreases while gravitational potential energy increases (because height increases). At the maximum height, all kinetic energy has been converted to potential energy and the ball momentarily stops. As it falls, the reverse occurs - potential energy converts back to kinetic energy. At each point, the sum of kinetic and potential energy equals the initial kinetic energy (ignoring air resistance). This demonstrates conservation of mechanical energy: one form decreases as the other increases, but the total remains constant.

extendedAbstract.question: How does the concept of energy efficiency connect to Australia's climate change response?
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: Energy efficiency fundamentally shapes climate response in multiple ways. First, inefficient energy use means more energy must be generated - if coal-fired, this produces more emissions. Improving efficiency reduces emissions without reducing services. Second, efficiency improvements are often the cheapest way to reduce emissions - better insulation, LED lighting, and efficient appliances can save money while cutting emissions. Third, as we transition to renewables, efficiency makes the transition easier - less renewable capacity is needed if we use energy more efficiently. Fourth, the efficiency of energy storage and conversion affects how much renewable energy can be integrated - losses in storage and transmission matter for grid design. Finally, understanding efficiency helps evaluate claims about energy technologies - knowing that no process is 100% efficient helps identify unrealistic promises. Australia's Minimum Energy Performance Standards and energy rating labels apply these physics concepts to policy, showing how scientific understanding informs climate action.

studentReflection: How does understanding energy efficiency change how you think about choosing appliances or technology?
What everyday activities could you modify to use energy more efficiently?
Why do you think energy storage is such an important challenge for renewable energy?

C.levelDescription: Year-level appropriate content meeting Victorian Curriculum standards
whatYouWillLearn: How to apply conservation of energy to complex systems
The relationship between work, energy, and the work-energy theorem
How to analyse energy transformations including heat losses
Quantitative analysis of efficiency and power in real systems
The physics of renewable energy technologies

sections.title: The Work-Energy Theorem
sections.content: The work-energy theorem states that the net work done on an object equals its change in kinetic energy: W_net = ΔKE = ½mv₂² - ½mv₁². This theorem connects force-based analysis with energy-based analysis. When you accelerate a car, the engine does positive work, increasing kinetic energy. When you brake, friction does negative work, decreasing kinetic energy. The theorem applies regardless of the path taken or forces involved - only the net effect on kinetic energy matters. This provides an alternative problem-solving approach to Newton's laws, particularly useful when forces vary over a displacement.
sections.visualDescription: Diagram showing work done by various forces and resulting change in kinetic energy

sections.title: Conservative and Non-Conservative Forces
sections.content: Conservative forces (like gravity) have work that depends only on starting and ending positions, not the path taken. For conservative forces, mechanical energy is conserved - you can 'get back' the energy by reversing the process. Non-conservative forces (like friction) depend on the path and dissipate mechanical energy as heat. When friction acts, mechanical energy decreases: KE₁ + GPE₁ = KE₂ + GPE₂ + W_friction. The 'lost' energy becomes thermal energy in the objects and surroundings. Understanding which forces are conservative helps determine when and how to apply energy conservation.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison of paths for conservative force (same work) versus non-conservative force (path-dependent work)

sections.title: Elastic Potential Energy
sections.content: Springs and other elastic materials store energy when deformed. The elastic potential energy in a spring is EPE = ½kx², where k is the spring constant (in N/m) and x is the displacement from equilibrium (in m). The spring constant describes stiffness - higher k means more force required for the same extension. When a spring is released, elastic potential energy converts to kinetic energy. In an ideal spring, this conversion is completely reversible - the system oscillates indefinitely. Real springs lose energy to internal friction, eventually coming to rest.
sections.visualDescription: Spring system showing elastic potential energy at maximum compression and kinetic energy at equilibrium

sections.title: Energy in Collisions
sections.content: Collisions involve rapid energy transformations. In elastic collisions, kinetic energy is conserved (as well as momentum). In inelastic collisions, some kinetic energy converts to other forms - primarily thermal energy and sound. For perfectly inelastic collisions where objects stick together, maximum kinetic energy is lost while still conserving momentum. The coefficient of restitution (e) relates the kinetic energy lost: for elastic collisions e = 1; for perfectly inelastic e = 0. Crash safety engineering focuses on managing energy transformation during collisions - dissipating kinetic energy while minimizing forces on occupants.
sections.visualDescription: Before/after diagrams comparing elastic and inelastic collisions with energy calculations

sections.title: Efficiency in Complex Systems
sections.content: Real systems involve multiple energy transformations, each with some losses. For a series of transformations, overall efficiency is the product of individual efficiencies. A coal power station (40% efficient) transmitting power (95% efficient) to an electric heater (100% efficient) has overall efficiency of 0.40 × 0.95 × 1.00 = 38%. Sankey diagrams visualize energy flows, showing useful outputs and losses at each stage. For complex systems like cars, multiple efficiencies compound: fuel energy → engine heat → mechanical energy → drivetrain losses → wheel energy. Identifying the largest losses helps prioritize improvements.
sections.visualDescription: Multi-stage Sankey diagram showing energy flow through a power generation and transmission system

sections.title: Renewable Energy Physics
sections.content: Different renewable technologies exploit different energy sources. Solar photovoltaics convert light energy directly to electrical energy via the photoelectric effect, with efficiencies now reaching 20-25% commercially. Wind turbines convert air kinetic energy to rotational mechanical energy then to electricity, with theoretical maximum efficiency of 59% (Betz limit) and practical efficiencies around 40-50%. Hydroelectric systems convert gravitational potential energy to electrical energy with efficiencies of 80-90%. Biofuels store solar energy through photosynthesis, then release it through combustion. Each technology's physics determines its potential and limitations.
sections.visualDescription: Diagrams showing energy transformations in solar, wind, and hydro systems with typical efficiencies

sections.title: Energy Storage Technologies
sections.content: Energy storage addresses the mismatch between energy supply and demand. Batteries store electrical energy chemically, with lithium-ion batteries achieving about 85-95% round-trip efficiency. Pumped hydro stores energy as gravitational potential energy at about 70-85% efficiency. Hydrogen production by electrolysis (about 70% efficient) and later fuel cells (about 50% efficient) gives overall round-trip efficiency of about 35%. Compressed air energy storage is about 40-70% efficient. Thermal storage holds energy as heat. Each technology suits different applications based on efficiency, capacity, cost, and response time.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison chart of energy storage technologies with efficiency, capacity, and application data

sections.title: Australia's Energy Transition
sections.content: Australia is transitioning its energy system from fossil fuels to renewables. This involves transforming electricity generation (replacing coal with solar and wind), electrifying transport (EVs replacing petrol cars), and decarbonising industry (electric or hydrogen processes replacing gas). The physics challenges include: managing variable renewable generation, storing energy for demand matching, transmitting renewable energy from remote locations to population centres, and converting high-temperature industrial processes. The National Electricity Market coordinates supply and demand across eastern Australia. Understanding energy transformations and efficiency is essential for planning and evaluating this transition.
sections.visualDescription: Map showing Australia's renewable energy zones, transmission corridors, and storage projects

caseStudy.title: Rollercoaster Physics: Conservation in Action
caseStudy.content: Rollercoasters are demonstrations of energy conservation principles. At Movie World on the Gold Coast, the DC Rivals HyperCoaster reaches speeds over 115 km/h and heights of 61 metres. The initial climb uses a motor to do work on the train, increasing its gravitational potential energy. At the top, the train has maximum potential energy and minimal kinetic energy. As it descends, potential energy converts to kinetic energy - the train accelerates without any motor. The first hill is always the highest because energy is gradually lost to friction and air resistance. Engineers calculate required heights based on desired speeds: v = √(2gh) gives the maximum speed achievable from height h. The actual speed is less because of energy losses. Loops require careful analysis - the train needs enough kinetic energy at the loop's top to maintain contact with the track. Too fast causes uncomfortable g-forces; too slow causes the train to fall. Modern designs use teardrop-shaped loops (clothoid curves) to maintain more constant g-forces. Computer modeling applies conservation of energy with friction and drag corrections to optimize the ride. The physics ensures both thrill and safety.
questions: Why must the first hill of a rollercoaster be higher than any subsequent hills?
How would you calculate the minimum height for a vertical loop of radius r?
Why do modern rollercoasters use teardrop-shaped loops instead of circular ones?

remember.question: State the work-energy theorem.
remember.sampleAnswer: The work-energy theorem states that the net work done on an object equals its change in kinetic energy: W_net = ΔKE = ½mv₂² - ½mv₁².

understand.question: Explain why friction is described as a 'non-conservative' force.
understand.sampleAnswer: Friction is non-conservative because the work it does depends on the path taken, not just the start and end points. If you slide an object along a short path, friction does less work than if you slide it along a longer path between the same two points. Also, friction converts mechanical energy into thermal energy, which doesn't convert back - you can't recover the mechanical energy by reversing the process. This contrasts with conservative forces like gravity, where energy can be recovered by returning to the starting position.

apply.question: A 50 kg skier starts from rest at the top of a 20 m high slope and reaches the bottom at 15 m/s. Calculate the energy lost to friction.
apply.sampleAnswer: Initial energy = GPE at top = mgh = 50 × 9.8 × 20 = 9800 J. Final energy = KE at bottom = ½mv² = ½ × 50 × 15² = 5625 J. Energy lost to friction = Initial - Final = 9800 - 5625 = 4175 J. About 43% of the initial energy was lost to friction between the skis and snow.

analyse.question: A basketball is dropped from 2.0 m and bounces to a height of 1.4 m. Analyse the energy transformations and calculate the ball's efficiency.
analyse.sampleAnswer: Initial GPE = mgh₁ = m × 9.8 × 2.0 = 19.6m J. This converts to KE as the ball falls. On impact, the ball deforms - KE converts to elastic PE and heat. As the ball rebounds, elastic PE converts back to KE, but some energy remains as thermal energy in the ball and floor. The ball rises to 1.4 m: Final GPE = m × 9.8 × 1.4 = 13.7m J. Energy lost = 19.6m - 13.7m = 5.9m J. Efficiency = (output/input) × 100% = (13.7m/19.6m) × 100% = 70%. The ball is 70% efficient, losing 30% per bounce to heat and sound.

evaluate.question: Evaluate whether hydrogen is a good energy storage medium for Australia's renewable energy transition, considering the physics of energy transformations.
evaluate.sampleAnswer: From an energy physics perspective, hydrogen has significant limitations but also advantages. Limitations: Electrolysis to produce hydrogen is about 70% efficient; compressing or liquefying hydrogen for storage loses another 10-15%; reconversion via fuel cell is about 50% efficient. Overall round-trip efficiency is therefore about 30-35% - much lower than batteries (85-95%) or pumped hydro (70-85%). This low efficiency means more renewable energy is needed to deliver the same final energy. Advantages: Hydrogen has very high energy density by mass (though not by volume), making it suitable for long-distance transport and shipping. It can be stored long-term without losses. It can serve sectors difficult to electrify directly (steel, chemicals, aviation). Australia's abundant solar and wind resources may make the efficiency penalty acceptable if electricity is very cheap. Evaluation: Hydrogen is likely a niche solution for specific applications (export, heavy industry, long-distance transport) rather than a general-purpose storage medium, due to efficiency losses. Batteries and pumped hydro are preferable where they're feasible.

create.question: Design an experiment to measure the efficiency of a model solar-powered motor lifting a small mass, identifying all energy transfers.
create.sampleAnswer: Equipment: Small solar panel, DC motor with pulley, known mass, ruler, stopwatch, light source with known power, power meter/multimeter. Procedure: 1) Measure light power incident on the solar panel using the power meter. 2) Connect solar panel to motor and measure electrical output (voltage × current). 3) Attach mass to motor pulley and measure time to lift mass a measured height. 4) Calculate energies at each stage. Calculations: Light energy input = incident power × time × panel area / beam area. Electrical energy output = voltage × current × time. Mechanical energy output = mgh. Efficiencies: Solar panel = electrical output / light input. Motor = mechanical output / electrical input. Overall = mechanical output / light input. Energy transfers: Light → electrical (solar panel, losses as reflection and heat) → electrical in wires (small resistive losses) → mechanical rotation (motor, losses as heat and friction) → gravitational PE of mass. Controls: Same light intensity, consistent setup, multiple trials. Error analysis: Consider measurement uncertainties in all quantities.

unistructural.question: What is the formula for elastic potential energy in a spring?
unistructural.sampleAnswer: EPE = ½kx², where k is the spring constant and x is the displacement from equilibrium.

multistructural.question: List four energy storage technologies and state a typical efficiency for each.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: 1) Lithium-ion batteries: 85-95% round-trip efficiency. 2) Pumped hydroelectric storage: 70-85% round-trip efficiency. 3) Hydrogen (electrolysis + fuel cell): 30-35% round-trip efficiency. 4) Compressed air energy storage: 40-70% round-trip efficiency.

relational.question: Explain how the work-energy theorem relates to conservation of energy.
relational.sampleAnswer: The work-energy theorem states that net work equals change in kinetic energy. Conservation of energy states that total energy remains constant. These are connected because work is the mechanism by which energy is transferred between objects and between forms. When positive work is done on an object, its kinetic energy increases - this energy comes from somewhere (e.g., chemical energy in muscles, electrical energy in a motor). When negative work is done, kinetic energy decreases - this energy goes somewhere (often thermal energy via friction). The work-energy theorem describes one object's energy change; conservation of energy ensures that when we account for all objects and all energy forms, the total remains constant. The theorem is essentially a focused application of conservation to kinetic energy changes.

extendedAbstract.question: How do the laws of thermodynamics, particularly the second law, relate to and constrain the application of energy conservation?
extendedAbstract.sampleAnswer: The first law of thermodynamics is essentially conservation of energy applied to thermal systems: energy is neither created nor destroyed, only transformed. However, the second law imposes a critical constraint on what transformations are possible. While total energy is conserved, not all energy is equally useful. The second law states that entropy (disorder) in an isolated system always increases. This means energy transformations inevitably produce some thermal energy that disperses into the surroundings and cannot be completely recovered. This explains why no heat engine is 100% efficient - some energy must be rejected as waste heat to satisfy the second law. The Carnot efficiency (1 - T_cold/T_hot) sets the maximum possible efficiency. This constrains renewable energy technology: solar cells have thermodynamic efficiency limits based on the Sun's temperature; heat-based power generation faces Carnot limits. The second law also explains why heat flows spontaneously from hot to cold but not reverse, why perpetual motion machines are impossible, and why the universe tends toward thermal equilibrium. So while energy is conserved (first law), it becomes progressively less available for doing work (second law), giving time's arrow and setting fundamental limits on technology.

studentReflection: How does understanding energy efficiency change your perspective on different energy technologies?
What role should energy physics play in policy decisions about energy sources?
How do you reconcile conservation of energy with the everyday experience that energy seems to 'run out'?

whatYouWillLearn: Advanced applications of energy conservation including rotational systems
Thermodynamic constraints on energy transformations
Analysis of complex multi-stage energy systems
Energy analysis in astrophysical and engineering contexts
Critical evaluation of energy technologies and policies

sections.title: Rotational Kinetic Energy
sections.content: Objects rotating about an axis have rotational kinetic energy: KE_rot = ½Iω², where I is the moment of inertia (analogous to mass) and ω is angular velocity. The moment of inertia depends on mass distribution - mass farther from the rotation axis contributes more to I. For a rolling object, total kinetic energy is the sum of translational and rotational components: KE_total = ½mv² + ½Iω². For rolling without slipping, v = ωr, linking the two. A solid sphere has I = 2/5 mr², so rolling downhill it has KE = ½mv² + ½(2/5 mr²)(v/r)² = ½mv² + 1/5 mv² = 7/10 mv². This is less than a sliding object's ½mv², explaining why rolling objects accelerate more slowly on inclines.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison of different shapes rolling down an incline with different moments of inertia

sections.title: Thermodynamics and Energy Quality
sections.content: The second law of thermodynamics establishes that energy has quality as well as quantity. Entropy measures disorder and always increases for isolated systems. High-quality energy (electrical, mechanical) can do work efficiently; low-quality energy (low-temperature heat) cannot. Every energy transformation increases total entropy, degrading energy quality. The Carnot efficiency η = 1 - T_cold/T_hot sets the maximum possible heat engine efficiency. At typical power plant temperatures, Carnot efficiency might be 60-70%, but real engines achieve less due to irreversibilities. Exergy analysis quantifies the maximum useful work extractable from energy sources, accounting for environmental temperature. This framework explains why waste heat is difficult to use - its low temperature means low exergy.
sections.visualDescription: Temperature-entropy diagram showing Carnot cycle and irreversibilities in real engines

sections.title: Energy in Oscillating Systems
sections.content: In simple harmonic motion (SHM), energy continuously transforms between kinetic and potential forms. For a mass on a spring, total energy E = ½kA² (where A is amplitude) is constant. At maximum displacement, all energy is potential (½kx² = ½kA²); at equilibrium, all is kinetic (½mv² = ½kA²). At intermediate positions, energy is shared. The energy oscillates at twice the oscillation frequency - each half-cycle, energy converts fully from potential to kinetic and back. Damping causes gradual energy loss to heat, reducing amplitude exponentially. The Q-factor (quality factor) quantifies how many oscillations occur before energy reduces significantly, important in musical instruments and electronic circuits.
sections.visualDescription: Energy versus position graphs for simple harmonic motion showing kinetic, potential, and total energy

sections.title: Escape Velocity and Binding Energy
sections.content: Gravitational potential energy is negative by convention: GPE = -GMm/r, where G is the gravitational constant, M and m are masses, and r is separation. At infinite separation, GPE = 0. For an object to escape a gravitational field, its total energy (KE + GPE) must be at least zero. Setting ½mv² - GMm/r ≥ 0 gives escape velocity: v_escape = √(2GM/r). For Earth, this is about 11.2 km/s. Binding energy is the energy required to remove an object from a gravitational system, equal to the magnitude of its total negative energy. These concepts apply to satellites, rockets, and understanding why planets retain atmospheres (molecular speeds versus escape velocity).
sections.visualDescription: Energy diagram showing bound, unbound, and escape trajectories in a gravitational field

sections.title: Energy Analysis of Power Systems
sections.content: Modern power systems require comprehensive energy analysis. Primary energy (coal, solar radiation, wind) undergoes multiple transformations before reaching end users. Losses occur at each stage: generation (heat engine or conversion efficiency), transmission (resistive losses, typically 5-10%), distribution, and end-use devices. Combined cycle gas plants achieve about 60% efficiency by using waste heat to drive a second turbine. Cogeneration (combined heat and power) further improves overall efficiency by using 'waste' heat for space heating. Life cycle assessment considers energy embodied in equipment manufacture and disposal. Net energy analysis calculates energy return on energy invested (EROI) - the ratio of useful energy output to energy required for extraction/construction.
sections.visualDescription: Sankey diagram of national energy flow from primary sources through transformations to end uses

sections.title: Renewable Energy Engineering
sections.content: Renewable energy engineering applies physics principles to maximize energy capture. Solar PV efficiency depends on semiconductor band gaps - matching the solar spectrum requires different materials for different wavelength ranges (multi-junction cells). Concentrating solar thermal uses mirrors to focus solar energy, achieving high temperatures for efficient heat engines. Wind turbine design balances blade length (energy capture ∝ area ∝ r²) against structural challenges. The Betz limit (59.3%) arises because extracting all wind energy would stop the wind. Capacity factor (actual output / theoretical maximum) accounts for variable conditions - typically 20-30% for solar, 30-40% for wind in good locations. Grid integration requires understanding supply-demand matching and storage requirements.
sections.visualDescription: Technical diagrams of solar PV, concentrating solar, and wind turbine systems with efficiency factors

sections.title: Energy Economics and Policy
sections.content: Energy physics constrains but doesn't determine economic and policy outcomes. Levelised cost of energy (LCOE) calculates electricity cost accounting for capital, fuel, maintenance, and discount rates. Learning curves describe how costs decrease with deployment (solar PV has dropped about 20% per doubling of cumulative capacity). Externalities (climate damage, air pollution) represent costs not included in market prices - carbon pricing attempts to internalise these. Energy policy instruments include mandates (renewable targets), incentives (subsidies, tax credits), and regulations (efficiency standards). Physics knowledge helps evaluate claims - understanding efficiency limits reveals unrealistic promises, and thermodynamic constraints inform technology comparisons.
sections.visualDescription: Graphs showing LCOE trends for different technologies and learning curves for solar and batteries

sections.title: Future Energy Technologies
sections.content: Emerging technologies aim to overcome current limitations. Perovskite solar cells promise higher efficiency and lower cost than silicon. Solid-state batteries may improve energy density and safety. Next-generation nuclear (small modular reactors, molten salt designs) addresses safety and waste concerns. Nuclear fusion, if achieved, would provide nearly unlimited clean energy - ITER is testing feasibility. Advanced geothermal (enhanced geothermal systems) could access heat energy anywhere on Earth. Space-based solar power would capture sunlight continuously, beaming energy to Earth. Each technology faces physics challenges and engineering hurdles. Critical evaluation requires understanding both theoretical limits and practical obstacles.
sections.visualDescription: Comparison of current and emerging energy technologies with theoretical and practical efficiency limits

caseStudy.title: Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion: Extracting Energy from Temperature Differences
caseStudy.location: Tropical oceans with potential Australian applications
caseStudy.content: Ocean Thermal Energy Conversion (OTEC) exploits the temperature difference between warm surface water (about 25°C) and cold deep water (about 5°C) in tropical oceans. This difference drives a heat engine, converting thermal energy to electricity. The physics is straightforward: the Carnot efficiency for T_hot = 298 K and T_cold = 278 K is η = 1 - 278/298 = 6.7%. Real systems achieve about 3-4% efficiency. While this seems low, the ocean contains enormous thermal energy - about 1000 times humanity's total energy consumption is available in principle. Australia's tropical waters are suitable for OTEC, with potential sites along the northern coast. Challenges are significant: the low temperature difference requires moving vast quantities of water; the cold water pipe extends to 1000+ metres depth; and infrastructure costs are high. Current projects are small-scale demonstrations in Hawaii and Japan. Economic viability requires either very cheap construction or additional revenue from cold water applications (aquaculture, air conditioning). OTEC illustrates how thermodynamic principles set fundamental efficiency limits while engineering determines practical feasibility. The technology may become viable as other renewable sources face land-use constraints or as deep-water pipe technology improves.
questions: Calculate the Carnot efficiency for OTEC and explain why actual efficiency is lower.
Why does low efficiency not necessarily make OTEC unviable?
What co-benefits might improve OTEC economics?

remember.question: State the formula for escape velocity and explain the significance of each term.
remember.sampleAnswer: Escape velocity is v_escape = √(2GM/r), where G is the gravitational constant (6.67 × 10⁻¹¹ N·m²/kg²), M is the mass of the body being escaped from, and r is the distance from the centre of that body. The formula arises from requiring total energy (kinetic + potential) to be at least zero, allowing the object to reach infinite distance with zero or positive velocity remaining.

understand.question: Explain why a hollow sphere and a solid sphere of the same mass and radius, rolling down the same incline, reach the bottom with different velocities.
understand.sampleAnswer: Both objects lose the same gravitational potential energy (mgh), which converts to kinetic energy. However, kinetic energy is divided between translational (½mv²) and rotational (½Iω²) components. For rolling without slipping, ω = v/r. The hollow sphere has moment of inertia I = 2/3 mr² while the solid sphere has I = 2/5 mr². More of the hollow sphere's energy goes into rotation (it has mass concentrated at larger radius), leaving less for translation. Thus the solid sphere reaches higher linear velocity despite both having the same total kinetic energy. This demonstrates how energy distribution, not just conservation, determines outcomes.

apply.question: A heat engine operates between 600 K (hot reservoir) and 300 K (cold reservoir). If the engine has an efficiency of 35%, calculate its actual power output if it receives 500 kW of heat input, and determine how much waste heat is produced.
apply.sampleAnswer: Carnot efficiency = 1 - T_cold/T_hot = 1 - 300/600 = 50%. The engine operates at 35%, which is below the Carnot limit (as required by thermodynamics). Power output = efficiency × heat input = 0.35 × 500 kW = 175 kW. By energy conservation, waste heat = input - output = 500 - 175 = 325 kW. The engine rejects 325 kW of waste heat to the cold reservoir while producing 175 kW of useful work.

analyse.question: Analyse why the EROI (energy return on energy invested) for fossil fuels has been declining over time, and what this implies for the energy transition.
analyse.sampleAnswer: EROI measures useful energy output per unit of energy invested in extraction. Early oil and gas had EROI of 100:1 or higher - easily accessible deposits required minimal energy to extract. As these 'easy' reserves depleted, extraction moved to more challenging locations (deep water, Arctic, tight shale), requiring more energy for drilling, pumping, and processing. Current conventional oil has EROI around 10-20:1; tar sands and shale oil may be 5-10:1. For renewable energy: solar PV has EROI of 10-20:1, wind 20-50:1, both improving with technology. Implications for the transition: 1) Fossil fuels become progressively less favorable energetically, not just economically. 2) Once EROI falls below about 5:1, barely enough energy remains for society after meeting energy sector needs. 3) Renewables' improving EROI contrasts with declining fossil fuel EROI, suggesting an energy logic for transition beyond climate concerns. 4) However, transition itself requires energy investment, temporarily reducing net energy available to society.

evaluate.question: Evaluate the claim that nuclear fusion will provide 'limitless clean energy' once achieved, considering thermodynamic and practical constraints.
evaluate.sampleAnswer: The 'limitless' claim has both validity and important caveats. Valid aspects: Fusion fuel (deuterium from water, lithium for tritium breeding) is abundant enough for millions of years. Fusion energy per reaction is enormous, with potential for high power density. Waste products (helium) are benign; induced radioactivity in reactor materials is much shorter-lived than fission waste. Caveats and constraints: 'Limitless' ignores practical limits on reactor construction and grid integration. Fusion still obeys thermodynamic laws - heat engines converting fusion heat to electricity face Carnot limits (perhaps 40-50% efficiency). Capital costs may be enormous - ITER is over €20 billion and produces no net power. Advanced confinement schemes may reduce costs but remain unproven. Neutron damage limits reactor lifetime and creates radioactive waste requiring management. Tritium is radioactive, though short-lived. 'Clean' is relative - fusion is cleaner than fission and far cleaner than fossil fuels, but not zero-impact. Evaluation: Fusion, if achieved economically, would be a remarkable energy source, but the language of 'limitless and clean' oversimplifies real physics and engineering constraints.

create.question: Design an energy storage system for a remote Australian community transitioning to 100% renewable electricity, considering the physics of energy storage and practical requirements.
create.sampleAnswer: Design for a 500-person community with 500 kW peak demand and 3000 kWh daily consumption: Generation: 1 MW solar PV providing about 5 MWh/day average in good Australian conditions. Typical capacity factor ~25%. Storage requirements: The community needs to bridge night-time and cloudy periods. A 3-day autonomy target requires 9000 kWh storage. Primary storage: Lithium-ion batteries with 4000 kWh capacity (about one day), providing rapid response and high efficiency (90%). This handles normal overnight and cloudy period bridging. Round-trip losses: about 400 kWh per cycle. Secondary storage: Hydrogen system for extended backup. 5000 kWh capacity as hydrogen. Electrolyser (500 kW) operates during solar excess; fuel cells reconvert during extended shortages. Round-trip efficiency about 35%, but provides long-duration backup without battery degradation. Hydrogen can also fuel local transport. System operation: Smart controls prioritize battery use for normal fluctuations (high efficiency), hydrogen system for multi-day events. Hydrogen system also provides seasonal storage - summer solar excess stored for winter. Physics considerations: Battery degradation modeled to size for 10-year life; hydrogen storage pressure and volume calculated; thermal management for both systems; safety systems for hydrogen handling. Total cost estimate: approximately $8-10 million installed. This exceeds diesel generator costs but provides long-term fuel cost savings and emissions reduction.

unistructural.question: What is the Carnot efficiency formula?
unistructural.sampleAnswer: η_Carnot = 1 - T_cold/T_hot, where temperatures are in Kelvin.

multistructural.question: List four factors that affect the efficiency of a real heat engine compared to the Carnot efficiency.
multistructural.sampleAnswer: 1) Friction in moving parts converts mechanical energy to unusable heat. 2) Heat losses through engine walls reduce energy available for work. 3) Non-ideal heat transfer processes (requiring temperature differences to drive heat flow) reduce efficiency. 4) Non-reversible expansion and compression processes create entropy increase. 5) Incomplete combustion means not all fuel energy is released.

relational.question: Explain the relationship between energy quality, entropy, and the limitations of energy technologies.
relational.sampleAnswer: Energy quality refers to energy's ability to do useful work - high-temperature thermal energy has high quality; low-temperature heat has low quality. Entropy measures disorder; the second law states entropy always increases in isolated systems. Every energy transformation produces entropy, degrading energy quality. This relationship constrains technology: heat engines cannot convert all heat to work because some must be rejected at lower temperature (Carnot limit). Even non-thermal conversions (chemical, electrical) involve irreversibilities producing entropy. The practical implication is that efficiency has fundamental limits beyond engineering - no amount of improvement can exceed thermodynamic limits. This connects to sustainability: using high-quality energy (fossil fuels, electricity) for low-quality purposes (space heating) wastes energy quality. Optimal systems match energy quality to end-use requirements.
